title: Denis Classification -- Definition/Introduction
content: There have been several proposed classification systems to define thoracolumbar fractures.  In 1983, Francis Denis described a novel classification system to facilitate the communication of these fractures and their treatments among different medical professionals. [1] In his study, he retrospectively analyzed 412 thoracolumbar injuries and developed a three-column theory, replacing the previous two-column theory popularized by Sir Frank Holdsworth. [2] This newly-defined three-column theory would become the foundation for a classification system that would become widely adopted by spine surgeons to formulate treatment algorithms of thoracolumbar injuries.

title: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern
content: Under the Denis classification system, the spine gets subdivided into three columns with the included elements:

title: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern -- Anterior Column
content: Anterior longitudinal ligament (ALL) Anterior two-thirds of the vertebral body and annulus
contents: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern -- Anterior Column. Anterior longitudinal ligament (ALL) Anterior two-thirds of the vertebral body and annulus

title: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern -- Middle Column
content: Posterior one-third of the vertebral body and annulus Posterior vertebral wall Posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL)
contents: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern -- Middle Column. Posterior one-third of the vertebral body and annulus Posterior vertebral wall Posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL)

title: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern -- Posterior Column
content: All structures posterior to the PLL, including the posterior bony arch and the posterior ligamentous complex (supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, capsule, and ligamentum flavum)

title: Denis Classification -- Issues of Concern
content: The impetus in creating this third column was to describe the inherent instability of this middle column. [1] [3] Fractures involving the middle column were considered unstable with injury to the posterior longitudinal ligament in addition to the posterior annulus fibrosis, while isolated complete disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex was insufficient to prompt frank instability. title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance
content: Based on the findings in his study, Denis went on to classify thoracolumbar injuries into four major types, based on column involvement and mechanisms of injury:

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 1. Compression
content: Structures involved: Fracture of the anterior column of the vertebral body with an intact middle column Failure of the anterior column in compression May involve the superior or inferior endplate, or both Mechanism Anterior flexion & axial loading

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 2. Burst
content: Structures involved: Compression fractures of the anterior and middle columns.  The posterior column may or may not be involved if lamina fractures are present or if dural tears or nerve entrapments occur May involve the superior or inferior endplate, or both Mechanism Axial compression

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 3. Flexion-Distraction (Seatbelt-Type)
content: Structures involved: Usually involvement of all three columns No associated translation Mechanism
contents: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 3. Flexion-Distraction (Seatbelt-Type). Structures involved: Usually involvement of all three columns No associated translation Mechanism

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 3. Flexion-Distraction (Seatbelt-Type)
content: Flexion injuries to the middle and posterior columns with distraction posteriorly from tensile forces.  The ALL serves as the axis of rotation, and the anterior column may fail secondary to compression.

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 4. Fracture-Dislocation
content: Structures involved: Involvement of all three columns Mechanism Variable mechanisms: shear, rotation, compression, and tension
contents: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 4. Fracture-Dislocation. Structures involved: Involvement of all three columns Mechanism Variable mechanisms: shear, rotation, compression, and tension

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- 4. Fracture-Dislocation
content: The classification systems for thoracolumbar injuries have evolved over time. However, there is no universally accepted system yet at this time.  As such, there is not a current standardized treatment algorithm explicitly designed for the Denis classification.  Instead, general treatment principles may be applied to the following fractures, although significant controversy still exists in operative indications:

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- Compression Fractures
content: Nonoperative: Bracing, kyphoplasty/vertebroplasty Operative: Posterior instrumentation and fusion Indications [9] : 30 degrees traumatic kyphosis 50% vertebral body height loss

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- Burst Fractures
content: Nonoperative: Bracing Operative: Anterior/posterior decompression and instrumented fusion Indications: Neurologic deficit Spinal canal compromise Degree of deformity Disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex
contents: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- Burst Fractures. Nonoperative: Bracing Operative: Anterior/posterior decompression and instrumented fusion Indications: Neurologic deficit Spinal canal compromise Degree of deformity Disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- Flexion-Distraction Injuries
content: Nonoperative: Bracing Indications: minimally displaced bony or ligamentous injuries Operative [10] : Posterior instrumentation, with or without fusion Indications: kyphotic deformity greater than 20 degrees

title: Denis Classification -- Clinical Significance -- Fracture Dislocation Injuries
content: Operative: All require open reduction with instrumented fusion

title: Denis Classification -- Nursing, Allied Health, and Interprofessional Team Interventions
content: Nursing staff in orthopedic or neurosurgical practice should be familiar with the Denis classification so they can appropriately counsel patients regarding their condition, speak confidently and knowledgeably with other providers about cases, and alert clinicians to potential issues of concern should they be the first to encounter them.
